I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The global financial crisis showed the Government of the Philippines that it had to 
strengthen its supervision of the financial sector by working out long-standing weaknesses in 
governance and administration in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the 
Insurance Commission. A recent Financial Sector Assessment Program of the International 
Monetary Fund (IMF) also brought out the need for a more developed capital market to reduce 
concentration risk. The government has therefore made financial sector reform a priority and 
taken  the  first  step  of  appointing  key  champions  of  reform  to  lead  the  nonbank  financial 
regulators.  Subprogram  2  of  the  Financial  Market  Regulation  and  Intermediation  Program 
(FMRIP-02)  reinforces  this  reform  effort  and  is  designed  to  deepen  the  financial  markets, 
broaden the investor base, and strengthen policy and regulatory capabilities.1 Recent missions 
have likewise noted a growing consistency between the government, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), and a wide range of stakeholders, including the private sector, in their identified 
development constraints and reform priorities.  
 
2.  To build on this momentum for reform, the government has requested ADB technical 
assistance (TA) to support the implementation of policy actions agreed to under the Post 
Program Partnership Framework (P3F) of FMRIP-02. The P3F calls for stronger collective 
oversight  of  the  financial  markets  by  the  government  through  the  Financial  Sector  Forum 
(FSF).2 In addition, the government will implement the SEC’s restructuring action plan. With the 
support of increased budget allocations, the TA will improve the operational capabilities and 
strengthen prudential oversight by the SEC. Finally, the government will implement the priority 
recommendations of the Financial Sector Assessment Program, particularly those that have a 
bearing on capital market development.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
A.  Poorly Coordinated Planning and Execution 
 
3.  Efforts to  develop  the Philippine  capital  markets  have  been  undermined  in  part  by 
insufficiently comprehensive planning and direction, and by a lack of consensus. The previous 
capital market development blueprint (2005–2010) was drawn up by the SEC, and participation 
in its drafting and implementation favored the SEC and the Philippine Stock Exchange, a 
SEC-regulated entity. The private sector contributed little to the plan, which turned out to be 
overly prescriptive. Only about 60% of its initiatives were completed. Many of the key cross-
agency development constraints, such as taxation, a poorly developed primary and secondary 
market for government debt securities, the absence of a risk-free yield curve, and a lack of long-
term savings were not addressed. 
 
4.  To  deal  with  these  issues,  the  government  has  released  a  new  capital  market 
development plan (CMDP), which it is implementing through the Philippine Development Plan 
for 2011–2016. With the CMDP, the government looks forward to easing key development 
constraints by consolidating the government debt markets, developing a risk-free yield curve,

Subprogram 2 to the Republic of the Philippines for the Financial Market Regulation and Intermediation Program. 
Manila. 
2  The Financial Sector Forum is a nonjudicial college of regulators that coordinates financial sector supervision. It is 
not empowered to issue regulations. Its members are the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (central bank), the Philippine

2   
 
accelerating growth in the contractual savings industry, continuously developing the capacity of 
financial  regulators,  rationalizing  and  harmonizing  financial  sector  taxes,  and  improving 
infrastructure (physical, legal, and governance, such as the credit information bureau, which is 
currently inactive). Legislative initiatives, such as the passage of the Personal Equity Retirement 
Account (PERA)3 Act of 2008, complement these initiatives. These objectives are consistent 
with  those  indicated  by  numerous  TA  projects  and  ADB-sponsored  diagnostics  within  the 
financial sector over the past 12 months.  
 
5.  Implementing  the  CMDP,  however,  demands  close  coordination  and  collaboration 
between agencies like the Treasury, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP, the central bank), 
the Department of Finance (DOF), and the SEC, and the private sector. Shared goals must be 
established and mutually dependent responsibilities assigned. Disputes between stakeholders 
must be carefully settled. Issues surrounding the primary and secondary government debt 
market must first be resolved to improve efficiency and pricing. The government can then push 
other reforms to remove barriers to stock listing and the flotation of corporate debt securities.4 
Consultations have confirmed the distinct cost advantage of bank loans relative to securities 
with their highly complex and costly process of issuance and distribution. At the same time, the 
government will need to provide an enabling environment for long-term savings while ensuring 
governance reforms and adequate protection for small savers. 
 
B.  Weak Supervision, Reducing Investor Confidence 
 
6.  Despite  considerable  improvements  in  quality  and  coordination,  financial  sector 
supervision continues to be hampered by weaknesses which dampen investor confidence. 
There are three separate regulators: the BSP for the banking sector; the SEC for the nonbank 
subsector; and the Insurance Commission for the insurance subsector. The FSF, formed in 
2004, has strengthened coordination. However, gaps in regulatory capacity and coverage, and 
poor enforcement of coordination arrangements have encouraged regulatory arbitrage among 
financial entities. Closing these gaps is a priority for the FSF, and it is expected to succeed 
eventually in this goal. For now, however, supervision remains uneven. Immediate efforts must 
be  made,  both  to  increase  capacity  and  to  set  the  stage  for  improved  cooperation  and 
information sharing. Better-coordinated approaches to supervision and regulation must be found 
for  complex  financial  conglomerates  and  the  common  products  delivered  by  unaffiliated 
providers across the financial subsectors. 
 
7.  The governance and operating weaknesses in the SEC and the Insurance Commission 
are due in large measure to a lack of fiscal and administrative autonomy. A limited budget and 
demanding noncore functions have curbed the capacity of SEC staff to address higher-value 
core functions. An inefficient corporate registration process is one particular consequence of 
budget inadequacy. Routine corporate registrations, which have greatly increased in volume, 
are still processed manually and use paper-based routines. Resources have to be diverted from 
other departments, at times, to allow corporate registration renewals to be processed during 
peak periods.  
 
8.  This processing burden has in turn delayed efforts to build and maintain an effective 
market surveillance and on-sight examination function. Market participants point out that the 
high costs of trading through the Philippine Dealing and Exchange Corporation, which is the 
                                                
3 Personal equity retirement accounts allow individual Filipinos to save and invest on a tax-deferred basis to provide 
for their retirement and will encourage long-term savings.  
4  Corporate issuance is also constrained by tax and regulatory disincentives and a weak insolvency regime.

3 
sole self-regulatory organization (SRO) for the bond market, evidences a need for stronger 
supervisory oversight. Further, the 2010 corporate governance report from leading independent 
brokerage and investment group CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets noted both anecdotal and more 
concrete evidence of weaknesses in the SEC’s oversight and supervision of market practices, 
including market integrity and financial reporting. 5 The lack of budget support compounds this 
problem by compromising the SEC’s ability to retain and develop staff that would allow it to 
provide an enabling, financially stable environment for capital market development.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
9.  The proposed TA will address the foregoing issues through two main areas of focus: 
(i) improving  the  government’s  capacity  to  facilitate  capital  market  development,  and 
(ii) strengthening  regulatory  capacity.  Efforts  to  encourage  the  development  of  the  capital 
markets will include recognized and specific activities to create an enabling environment. In 
addition, the assistance will sustain the government’s renewed efforts to build consensus on 
specific solutions to long-standing development constraints, across a varied stakeholder base. 
Such collaboration is a prerequisite to solving the more technical issues mentioned in para. 4 
above and represents a continuation of ADB’s engagement with the government over the past 
12 months. Activities to strengthen regulatory capacity will address the more pressing operating 
weaknesses as a prelude to establishing greater operating and fiscal autonomy in nonbank 
regulatory agencies, as envisioned in the P3F.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  TA  will  supplement  and  support  policy  actions  agreed  to  under  the  P3F  of 
FMRIP-02. Its impact will therefore mirror that of the FMRIP-02, which is an increase in the 
contribution of the nonbank financial sector to economic growth. The outcome of the TA will be 
a deeper, more diversified, and more resilient financial sector. To achieve this impact and 
outcome, incentives will be provided and barriers to capital market development will be removed. 
In addition, the quality of regulatory oversight will be strengthened and investor confidence will 
increase as a result. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology 
 
1.  Output 1: Improved Capacity for Capital Market Development  
 
11.  The CMDP promotes higher economic growth and effective delivery of financial services 
through a stronger, more stable, more transparent, and deeper financial system. The activities 
in this component of the TA will assist in the development of a comprehensive, sector-wide 
implementation  road  map  for  the  CMDP.  An  international  expert,  whose  services  will  be 
financed under the TA, will assist the Government to ensure that critical constraints are fully 
identified and that proposed corrective actions are effective and addressed in proper sequence. 
More  importantly,  advice  will  be  given  to  the  government  in  resolving  conflicts  between 
stakeholders.  
 
12.  To provide an enabling environment for long-term savings and at the same time increase 
the supply of capital market products, the TA will support the implementation of the PERA Act of 
2008, and provide for a comprehensive review and revision of the regulations for securities 
issuance and distribution. The resulting changes are expected to empower small savers while at

the same time simplifying the issuance and distribution process for securities, thereby lessening 
the relative cost advantage of bank loans.  
 
13.  Finally, the TA will improve the investment climate by funding the development of a 
corporate  governance  scorecard  linked  to  the  Maharlika  program  of  the  Philippine  Stock 
Exchange. Corporations with good corporate governance will be eligible for expedited and 
simplified processing of applications filed with the SEC. 
 
2.  Output 2: Stronger Regulatory Oversight and Enforcement in the Financial 
Sector  
 
14.  The activities in this component will improve inter-regulatory cooperation and reduce the 
opportunity  for  regulatory  arbitrage  by  backing  the  government’s  efforts  to  harmonize  the 
prudential supervision of private banking and wealth management beginning with a training 
course delivered simultaneously to all regulatory agencies through the FSF. By harmonizing 
knowledge,  the  FSF  can  then  serve  as  a  catalyst  for  the  development  of  synchronized 
regulations and supervisory processes by the individual regulators so that common financial 
products distributed by complex financial conglomerates or across financial subsectors are 
uniformly regulated.  
 
15.  A policy action under FMRIP-02 called for the SEC to develop a restructuring action plan. 
Under a second policy action, the Department of Budget and Management granted a significant 
budget increase, totaling $9.8 million over 2 years, to the SEC to fund a permanent increase in 
staff salaries as required under the revised Securities Regulation Code (2005), the hiring of 
additional permanent staff, and the upgrading of the technical capabilities and infrastructure of 
the SEC.6 The activities in this component will assist the SEC in achieving efficiency gains by 
providing high level advisory support for streamlining and automating corporate registration, with 
the allocated budget detailed above, which in turn will free up scarce resources within the SEC 
and enable the agency to focus on its core regulatory and supervisory duties. Ancillary benefits 
expected from the automation project will take the form of greatly improved information about 
the composition of the private sector corporate base in the Philippines for the use of economic 
planners and other stakeholders.  
 
16.  A  specific  budget  allocation  will  also  fund  the  purchase  of  improved  surveillance 
systems, which, in combination with the TA activities in this component, will directly strengthen 
the SEC’s capacity to conduct market surveillance and to prosecute violations of the Securities 
Regulation Code. In addition, this component will strengthen the SEC’s ability to supervise 
collective investment schemes and SROs, and to ensure that financial reporting complies with 
International Financial Reporting Standards to improve transparency.  
 
17.  Lessons learned. The proposed TA incorporates the lessons learned from the 2003 
ADB country assistance program evaluation.7   Specifically, FMRIP-02 and the proposed TA  
are  not  conditioned  on  the  passage  of  law,  as  the  legislative  process  in  the  country  is 
cumbersome  and  lengthy.  Further,  experience  has  shown  that  simply  changing  a  law  or 
regulation will not modify behavior without strong enforcement.  The proposed TA mirrors the 
strong reform agenda of the government. Intensive consultations with industry stakeholders 
have confirmed the wide acceptance and support that the reform agenda, in principle, enjoys 
                                                
6 The budget increase is allocated as follows: $3.9 million for salary adjustments, $5.9 million for improvements in 
process and infrastructure. 
7 ADB. 2003. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Philippines. Manila.

5 
among stakeholders. The reform agenda is also consistent with the Philippine Development 
Plan and the CMDP, as well as with agency reform priorities. The TA in support of CMDP 
implementation will reduce the risk that newer, more restrictive regulations are adopted. 
 
18.  Additional safeguards have been adopted in the form of three policy actions which serve 
as disbursement triggers in FMRIP-02. These triggers, which have been completed, ensure that 
the proposed reform priorities will be adequately managed and funded. First, the transfer of the 
SEC back to the DOF provides for added guidance and ensures the alignment of the agency’s 
priorities with those of the National Government. The acceptance of the SEC’s action plan of 
restructuring provided for common goals and a basis for budget negotiations with DBM. Finally, 
the approval of the SEC’s budget increase ensures funding is adequate to support the reform 
agenda. In addition, the recent appointment of new chairs to head the SEC and the Insurance 
Commission provide additional assurances that the DOF can exercise effective control over the 
nonbank regulatory agencies and the TA project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.2 million, of which,  $1.0 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and office 
accommodation. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The executing agency will be the DOF. The BSP will serve as an implementing agency 
for the PERA and FSF training program. The IC will serve as an implementing agency for the 
insurance diagnostic and training program. The SEC will serve as an implementing agency for 
the  balance  of  the  projects  contemplated  by  this  TA.  The  project  is  expected  to  start  on               
2 January 2012 and end on 31 December 2013.  
 
21.  ADB will hire consultants through quality- and cost-based selection (80:20), according to 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). National experts 
will be hired for implementation and capacity development in support of the launch of the PERA 
(output 1) and for the automation of SEC licensing and registration (output 2). International 
experts will provide the remaining TA services (outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3). 
Expressions of interest solicited from qualified consulting firms will establish the appropriate 
packaging of the consulting services (one or several packages, depending on market testing). 
Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved               
ADB  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000                             
to the Government of the Philippines to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Capacity Development of Financial Regulators, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Output 1: Improved Capacity for Capital Market Development  
1.  International Capital Markets Expert (3 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The consultant should have more than 10 years’ experience in financial and capital 
markets, a thorough understanding of international best practices and prudential requirements, 
and specific expertise in sequenced capital market development. The consultant must also be 
experienced in international benchmarking exercises covering regulation and underwriting within 
regional securities markets, and must have knowledge of the requirements associated with the 
regional  capital  market  integration  project  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN). The consultant will do the following:  
(i)  in consultation with the Department of Finance, the Securities and Exchange 
Commission, and other stakeholders, prepare a sequenced  implementation road 
map to support the Capital Market Development Plan; and 
(ii)  provide  continuing  advice  to  the  government  with  regard  to  implementation 
issues and sound practices to ensure that appropriate measures are adopted to 
support capital market development.  
2.  National Information Technology Expert (6 person-months, intermittent) 
2.  The consultant will help the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas launch the personal equity 
retirement accounts, and must therefore have a finance industry background and more than 
10 years’  experience  in  developing  comprehensive  databases  or  heading  major  database 
projects. The consultant will do the following: 
(i)  prepare operational hardware and database specifications; 
(ii)  assist in selecting the appropriate hardware and software for purchase, and 
make appropriate and specific recommendations for each; 
(iii)  install the systems; 
(iv)  develop the operating guidelines, including the overall strategy, management 
controls, operator guidelines, internal controls and audit processes, and data 
validation routines; and 
(v)  train staff as necessary and prepare an operations manual. 
3.   International Securities Market Expert (1.5 person-months, intermittent) 
3.  The consultant should have more than 10 years’ experience in the financial and capital 
markets, a thorough understanding of international best practices and prudential requirements, 
and specific expertise in securities underwriting. The consultant will also have experience in 
international  benchmarking  exercises  covering  regulation  and  underwriting  within  regional 
securities markets and knowledge of the requirements associated with the ASEAN regional 
capital market integration project. The consultant will do the following:    
(i)  hold a briefing on regulations governing the issuance, distribution, and sale of 
debt  and  equity  securities  in  regional  peer  countries  (Australia;  Hong  Kong, 
China; Japan; Republic of Korea; Malaysia; Singapore); and  
(ii)  review Philippine regulations governing the issuance, distribution, and sale of 
debt and equity securities, and recommend ways of simplifying the processes in

light of international sound practices and in accordance with regional integration 
initiatives. 
 
4.  International  Securities  Market  Governance  Expert  (3  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
4.  The expert should have more than 10 years’ experience in the financial and capital 
markets, a thorough understanding of international best practices and prudential requirements, 
and specific expertise in raising corporate governance standards in public companies. The 
consultant will also have experience in international benchmarking exercises covering corporate 
governance within regional securities markets and knowledge of the requirements associated 
with the ASEAN regional capital market integration project. The consultant will do the following:   
(i)  review  current corporate governance  standards  and  perform gap  analysis  to 
identify differences between Philippine standards and sound international and 
regional practices and determine which areas need to be strengthened; 
(ii)  in  conjunction  with  the  SEC  and  other  stakeholders,  develop  a  program  of 
expedited administration (approval, processing, and reporting) appropriate for 
public companies that practice good corporate governance; and 
(iii)  in conjunction with the SEC and other stakeholders, develop an industry-wide 
corporate  governance  scorecard  to  be  used  (a)  to  provide  a  road map  for 
improvements in corporate governance in public companies, and (b) to serve as 
qualification criterion for expedited administration. 
 
B.  Output 2: Strengthened Regulatory Oversight and Enforcement in the Financial 
Sector  
1.  International Financial Compliance Expert (1 person-month, continuous) 
5.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  15  years’  experience  in  regulatory  supervision  or 
compliance  management  in  an  internationally  active  financial  institution.  In  addition,  the 
consultant  will  have  extensive  experience  in  the  supervision  of  private  banking  or  wealth 
management operations and a basic knowledge of the product offerings sold through these 
delivery channels. The consultant will do the following: 
(i)  in coordination with the Financial Sector Forum, develop the scope and outline 
for  a  training  class  (3–5  business  days)  in  private  banking  and  wealth 
management;  
(ii)  prepare and deliver the training class with a training-the-trainer component; 
(iii)  draft training materials for use in subsequent class sessions; and 
(iv)  on the basis of feedback from class participants, make recommendations for 
additional, cross-agency training. 
2.  International Securities Market Supervision Expert – Surveillance (4 person-
months, intermittent) 
6.  The consultant will have at least 10 years’ experience and a thorough understanding of 
market surveillance and supervision for both debt and equity  securities, as well as of the 
prudential requirements in the financial and capital markets, the related accounting issues, and 
international best practices. The consultant should have a high level of expertise in at least one 
market surveillance system (for both debt and equity markets) and direct experience in the

investigation of abusive or illegal market practices and the subsequent prosecution of such 
cases. The consultant will do the following:  
(i)  hold  a  briefing  on  current  surveillance  approaches,  including  the  types  of

(ii)  train SEC staff to identify illegal and manipulative trading practices at a very 
early stage; 
(iii)  train SEC staff in the proper documentation of cases of illegal and manipulative 
trading under Philippine law to support the prosecution of such cases;  
(iv)  recommend preemptive measures to keep the market informed and to warn 
investors looking to invest in a company whose securities are the target of 
manipulation or abuse; 
(v)  recommend  suitable  cooperation  and  information-sharing  arrangements 
between domestic regulators and foreign regulators for market surveillance; and 
(vi)  develop  a  work  plan  to  close  the  remaining  gaps  in  securities  trading 
surveillance in the Philippine capital markets, patterned after model cases in 
neighboring economies (Australia; Hong Kong, China; Japan; Republic of Korea; 
Malaysia; Singapore). 
3.  International  Securities  Market  Supervision  Expert  –  Self  Regulatory 
Organizations (4 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The consultant will have at least 10 years’ experience and a thorough understanding of 
market supervision for both debt and equity securities, as well as of the prudential requirements 
in the financial and capital markets and international best practices. In addition, the consultant 
should have direct experience in the supervision and oversight of self-regulatory organizations 
(SROs), in both the debt and equity markets, and should have a basic understanding of such 
supervision and oversight practices in various international jurisdictions. The consultant will do 
the following:  
(i)  hold a briefing on the internationally recognized structure and responsibilities of 
SROs (in the debt and equity markets), including changes brought about by the 
global financial crisis; 
(ii)  develop appropriate memorandums of agreement to be adopted by the SEC and 
SROs in the Philippine debt and equity markets; 
(iii)  draft an examination program for SROs, including the examination procedures, 
documentation standards, and examination report; and 
(iv)  provide  training  for,  and  assist  in  the  planning  and  conduct  of,  an  on-site 
examination of one SRO. 
4.  International Accounting Expert (3 person-months, continuous) 
8.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years’  relevant  experience  and  a  thorough 
understanding  of  International  Accounting  Standards  and  International  Financial  Reporting 
Standards. In addition, the consultant should have direct experience, in a regulatory capacity, in 
the  critical  review  and  examination  of  public  financial  statements  for  compliance  with 
established content and disclosure standards, and should also have experience in the design 
and operation of automated systems that can be used in this review. The consultant will do the 
following:

12      Appendix 3   
 
(i)  assess SEC’s current review and examination procedures for public financial 
statements and compare these with standards in developed markets (Australia; 
Canada; Europe; Hong Kong, China; Singapore; United States); 
(ii)  conduct a training session in effective methods and automated techniques used 
in  the  review  and  examination  of  public  financial  statements  in  developed 
markets; and 
(iii)  develop or revise a system to augment the capacity of the SEC, in both quantity 
and quality, to review and assess public financial statements for compliance with 
International  Accounting  Standards  and  International  Financial  Reporting 
Standards. 
5.  International Insurance Expert (3 person-months, intermittent) 
9.  The consultant will have at least 10 years’ experience and a thorough understanding of 
insurance regulation and supervision, including the administration and resolution of troubled 
insurance companies. Candidates with experience in or knowledge of the pre-need business 
and broad knowledge of international sound practices will be given preference. The consultant 
will do the following:  
(i)  in consultation with the insurance commissioner, review and assess the financial 
and  operating  condition  of  the  pre-need  sector,  including  the  extent  of  any 
deficiencies in reserves or capital; 
(ii)  in consultation with the insurance commissioner, review and assess the current 
surveillance and examination processes used to supervise the pre-need sector, 
and formulate an overall sector strategy; 
(iii)  recommend  a  risk-focused  examination  process  to  provide  efficient, 
cost-effective supervision of the mutual benefit association subsector; 
(iv)  draft revised surveillance and examination processes for the pre-need sector 
(prudential reporting formats, off-site surveillance and examination processes, 
and on-site examination processes, including examination procedures, reference 
manual, examination report, and follow-up methods); and 
(v)  provide training to support the implementation of the revised process. 
6.  National Information Technology Expert (12 person-months, intermittent) 
10.  The consultant should be an information technology specialist with more than 10 years’ 
experience in developing comprehensive databases or heading major database projects. The 
consultant, in coordination with and in support of the SEC, will do the following: 
(i)  in collaboration with SEC staff, develop standards, an initial workflow, and terms 
of  reference,  as  needed,  for  competitive  bidding  for  the  automation  and 
streamlining of corporate registration at the SEC; 
(ii)  support and advise the SEC through the bidding process, as needed; and 
(iii)  after the contract is awarded, monitor the work of the consultants hired directly by 
the SEC and serve as resource person providing constructive and, if necessary, 
critical feedback regarding project design, implementation, and progress.
